name: Forest – Boreal
definition: Distributed across the high latitudes of the northern hemisphere (occurring between 50 and 60° N) in a broad belt across Eurasia and North America. Trees are predominantly coniferous (pine, fir and spruce), though a few deciduous genera are nearly ubiquitous in their distribution and are locally common (see 1.4).
examples: Includes forest types described as taiga, coniferous, coniferous deciduous, and broadleaved deciduous.

name: Forest - Subarctic
definition: Included for completeness sake - probably little forest occurs at these high latitudes.

name: Forest – Subantarctic
definition: Stunted forest on subantarctic islands.
examples: Forest on Auckland and Snares Islands (to New Zealand), bosques sub-antárticos (Argentina).

name: Forest – Temperate
definition: Distributed in the temperate regions (under the influence of moist continental climates) of North and South America (primarily Chile), Europe, Asia (China/Korea/Japan) and Australia/New Zealand. Includes forest types described as coniferous, broadleaved evergreen, broadleaved deciduous, and mixed; also riverine and alluvial. The deciduous trees shed their leaves in the winter season. In the northern hemisphere, the coniferous (or needleleaf evergreen) component increases towards the north where the mixed forest transitions to Boreal Forest (see 1.1).
examples: Includes Mediterranean forests but these might also be placed under 1.5 [needs resolution] and pine-oak forests found in Mexico and the southern US.

name: Forest – Subtropical/tropical dry
definition: Distributed in the subtropical/tropical regions of the Neotropics, Africa and Indo-Malesia. Typically forests that experience a dry season of several months.
examples: Includes forest types described as deciduous, makatea, atoll/beach, palm, thorn and spiny; Florida rockland hammocks, pune rocklands, marine hammocks, shellmounds (last 4 from SE USA); bosque chaco, espinal, bosque de algarrobo/prosopis (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay); forest in the seasonally dry inter-Andean valleys.

name: Forest – Subtropical/tropical moist lowland
definition: Distributed in the subtropical/tropical regions of the Neotropics, Africa and Indo-Malesia, generally below c.1,200 m (but varying with geography and topography).
examples: Includes (lowland/hill rain/wet/humid/moist) forest types described as evergreen or semi-evergreen or broadleaved evergreen, deciduous, dipterocarp and mixed; also riparian/riverine and gallery, Sierra maestra se Cuba, selva paranaense, bosque de quebrada, bosque sammofilo (Uruguay)
vegetation.type.reflora: Floresta Ombrófila (= Floresta Pluvial)|Floresta Estacional Semidecidual|Floresta de Terra Firme|Floresta Ciliar ou Galeria|Floresta Estacional Perenifólia

name: Forest – Subtropical/tropical mangrove vegetation above high tide level
definition: Distributed in the subtropics and tropics, growing in sheltered estuaries and along coastlines in brackish or salt water

name: Forest – Subtropical/tropical swamp
definition: Distributed in the subtropics and tropics. Typically flooded for at least part of the year and dependent on this flooding for its existence.
examples: Includes forest types described as peat swamp, bog, and varzea/igapo.

name: Forest – Subtropical/tropical moist montane
definition: Distributed in the subtropical/tropical regions of the Neotropics, Africa and Indo-Malesia, generally above c.1,200 m (but varying with geography and topography).
examples: Includes (lower and upper montane/mountain rain/wet/moist) forest types described as cloud, mossy, elfin, dwarf, Polylepis, coniferous, pine, pine-oak and evergreen, mesophyllous, yungas (to Peru/Bolivia/Argentina).

name: Savanna - Dry
definition: (Needs to be defined)
examples: Includes savanna types described as Eucalyptus and Acacia woodland, mopane/miombo/Brachystegia woodlands (Africa), cerrado/campos/caatinga (Brazil, Guiana), chaco seco (Argentina/Uruguay) and mulga (Australia), oak woodlands (mid-western USA)

name: Savanna - Moist
definition: (Needs to be defined)
examples: Includes savanna types described as pantanal (Brazil/Bolivia/Paraguay), chaco or chaco húmedo (Paraguay/Bolivia/Argentina), and llanos (Venezuela/Colombia).

name: Shrubland – Subarctic
definition: (Needs to be defined)

name: Shrubland – Subantarctic
definition: (Needs to be defined)

name: Shrubland – Boreal
definition: (Needs to be defined)

name: Shrubland –Temperate
definition: (Needs to be defined) Compare to 3.5, 4.4 and 4.5

name: Shrubland – Subtropical/tropical dry
definition: (Needs to be defined) Found mainly on the lowlands. Compare to 3.5, 4.4 and 4.5
examples: Includes (arid/semi-desert/dry) shrubland types described as succulent, thorn or thorn scrub, karoo, strandveld (South Africa), Kalahari (Botswana, Namibia, South Africa), restingas (coastal scrub in Brazil); coastal strand; xerophyllous scrub; chapparal (Mexico and SW US); enclave, matorral sammofilo, matorral seco (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay).

name: Shrubland – Subtropical/tropical moist
definition: Humid/semi-humid shrubland types described as evergreen and found mainly on the lowlands
examples: Includes vegetation on river islands and in the riparian zones; matorral húmedo (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay)

name: Shrubland – Subtropical/tropical high altitude
definition: Alpine/subalpine shrubland types around and above the tree-line in mountainous regions.
examples: Some of the shrublands are dominated by rhododendron, juniper or birch; prepuna (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay).

name: Shrubland – Mediterranean-type shrubby vegetation
definition: Distributed in Mediterranean ecosystems of Australia, Chile, Europe/North Africa, North America (primarily California) and South Africa. Evergreen shrubs and sclerophyllous trees (low in stature with a relatively open canopy) are the dominant plant forms, and frequent fires have historically played an important role in regulating community composition and structure. The areas are characterized by warm dry summers.
examples: Includes shrubland types described as garrigue, chaparral (California), maquis (Mediterranean), mallee or mallee scrub (Australia), matorral (Chile) and fynbos (South Africa).

name: Grassland – Tundra
definition: Grasslands which have developed over permafrost. Confined to the northern hemisphere where it encircles the north pole and extends south to the Boreal Forests. The area is characterized by its extremely cold desert-like conditions.

name: Grassland – Subarctic
definition: Not defined

name: Grassland – Subantarctic
definition: Not defined
examples: Tussock grassland on subantarctic islands.

name: Grassland – Temperate
definition: Not defined. See 3.4, 3.5 and 4.5.
examples: Includes grassland types described as prairies (North America); steppe (Eurasia); calcareous; siliceous; edaphic; pampa or pampas (South America); pastizal patagónico, patagonia, pastizal pampeano (Argentina).

name: Grassland – Subtropical/tropical dry
definition: Not defined. See 3.4, 3.5 and 4.4.
examples: Includes (arid/dry) grassland types described as hummock/tussock (Australia); estepa (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay).

name: Grassland – Subtropical/tropical seasonally wet/flooded
definition: Not defined.

name: Grassland – Subtropical/tropical high altitude
definition: Sometimes also referred to as alpine tundra. The night time temperatures are usually below freezing, but the soils are well-drained.
examples: Includes (alpine/subalpine/highveld) grassland types described as paramos, altiplanos, puna, pastizal de altura.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Permanent rivers/streams/creeks (includes waterfalls)
definition: Not defined. Includes waterfalls.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Seasonal/intermittent/irregular rivers/streams/creeks
definition: Not defined.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Shrub dominated wetlands
definition: Shrub swamps, shrub-dominated freshwater marshes, shrub carr, alder thicket on inorganic soils.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Bogs, marshes, swamps, fens, peatlands
definition: Generally over 8 ha. Also includes mires.
examples: Bogs are peat-accumulating systems fed only by rainwater and thus have very low nutrient levels. They are usually strongly acidic, and water flow is restricted. The water table is either at or just below the surface and remains relatively constant.Fens have a predominantly peat substrate, but the peat is shallower and more decomposed than bogs. They are fed by both rain and groundwater resulting in low to moderate nutrient and acidity levels. The water table is typically just below the peat surface but there are small noticeable fluctuations.Swamps are relatively high in nutrients supplied via surface runoff and groundwater from the surrounding land. The water table is usually above some of the ground surface, but there are large, seasonal fluctuations. Marshes are characterized by large periodic fluctuations of water table or water level. Excludes saline marshes (see 5.16 and 5.17). Note that the size difference between marshes coded here versus under 5.7 or 5.8.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Permanent freshwater lakes (over 8 ha)
definition: Over 8 ha. Includes large oxbow lakes (see 13.5).
examples: Includes Caspian Sea

name: Wetlands (inland) – Seasonal/intermittent freshwater lakes (over 8 ha)
definition: Over 8 ha. Includes floodplain lakes (see 13.5).

name: Wetlands (inland) – Permanent freshwater marshes/pools (under 8 ha)
definition: Ponds (below 8 ha), marshes and swamps on inorganic soils; with emergent vegetation water-logged for at least most of the growing season.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Seasonal/intermittent freshwater marshes/pools (under 8 ha)
definition: Below 8 ha. On inorganic soils; includes sloughs, potholes, seasonally flooded meadows, sedge marshes.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Freshwater springs and oases
definition: Not defined.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Tundra wetlands (inc. pools and temporary waters from snowmelt)
definition: Includes tundra pools and temporary waters from snowmelt.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Alpine wetlands (inc. temporary waters from snowmelt)
definition: Includes alpine meadows, seepages, temporary waters from snowmelt.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Geothermal wetlands
definition: Wetlands influenced by heated geothermal water or chemistry derived from current or former geothermal activity. Often found in volcanically active areas.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Permanent inland deltas
definition: Created by a river dividing into multiple branches, these usually rejoin and continue to the sea. They often occur on former lake beds. In some cases a river flowing into a flat arid area splits into channels which then evaporate as it progresses into the desert.
examples: The Inner Niger Delta and Peace–Athabasca Delta are notable examples. The Amazon has an inland delta before the island of Marajó and the Okavango Delta is the best example of a desert inland delta .

name: Wetlands (inland) – Permanent saline, brackish or alkaline lakes
definition: Not defined.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Seasonal/intermittent saline, brackish or alkaline lakes and flats
definition: Not defined.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Permanent saline, brackish or alkaline marshes/pools
definition: Not defined.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Seasonal/intermittent saline, brackish or alkaline marshes/pools
definition: Not defined.
examples: Salinas in South America.

name: Wetlands (inland) – Karst and other subterranean hydrological systems (inland)
definition: Not defined.

group: 6. Rocky Areas (e.g., inland cliffs, mountain peaks)
name: Rocky Areas (e.g., inland cliffs, mountain peaks)
definition: Not defined.
examples: Includes inland cliffs, mountain peaks, talus, feldmark.

name: Caves and Subterranean Habitats (non-aquatic) – Caves
definition: Underground spaces produced naturally by the weathering of rock. Can extend deep underground, or can be much smaller rock

name: Caves and Subterranean Habitats (non-aquatic) – Other subterranean habitats
definition: Not defined.

name: Desert – Hot
definition: Not defined.
examples: [Deserts where the main form of precipitation is rain, thus would include the Arabian Desert; various Australian deserts - Great Sandy, Victoria, Simpson, Gibson and Sturt; Sahara; and the Thar in India].

name: Desert – Temperate
definition: Not defined.
examples: [Not clear, but might include the Takla Makan Desert in China, and the desert areas of Turkestan and possibly the Iranian Desert].

name: Desert – Cold
definition: Not defined.
examples: [Deserts where the main form of precipitation is snow or fog, and thus would include the Atacama Desert (Peru and Chile), Gobi Desert (China and Mongolia), Namib Desert (Namibia and bit of South Africa), Antarctica and parts of the Arctic].

name: Marine Neritic – Subtidal rock and rocky reefs

group: 11 Marine Deep Ocean Floor (Benthic and Demersal)
name: Continental Slope/Bathyl Zone (200–4,000 m)

group: 11 Marine Deep Ocean Floor (Benthic and Demersal)
name: Hard Substrate

group: 11 Marine Deep Ocean Floor (Benthic and Demersal)
name: Soft Substrate

group: 11 Marine Deep Ocean Floor (Benthic and Demersal)
name: Abyssal Plain (4,000–6,000 m)

group: 11 Marine Deep Ocean Floor (Benthic and Demersal)
name: Abyssal Mountain/Hills (4,000–6,000 m)

group: 11 Marine Deep Ocean Floor (Benthic and Demersal)
name: Hadal/Deep Sea Trench (>6,000 m)

group: 11 Marine Deep Ocean Floor (Benthic and Demersal)
name: Seamount

group: 11 Marine Deep Ocean Floor (Benthic and Demersal)
name: Deep Sea Vents (Rifts/Seeps)
Rocky Shoreline
definition: Intertidal shore composed predominantly of consolidated rock or boulders (see 9.2).

name: Sandy Shoreline and/or Beaches, Sand Bars, Spits, etc.
definition: Intertidal shore composed predominantly of sandy sediments (see 9.4 for sediment size characteristics).

name: Shingle and/or Pebble Shoreline and/or Beaches
definition: Intertidal shore composed predominantly of pebble and cobble sediments (see 9.3 for sediment size characteristics).

name: Mud Shoreline and Intertidal Mud Flats
definition: Intertidal shore or bottom composed predominantly of mud or sandy-mud sediments (see 9.4 and 9.5 for sediment size characteristics).

name: Salt Marshes (Emergent Grasses)
definition: A grassy area that extends along the shores of estuaries and sheltered coasts in temperate and subpolar regions with emergent vegetation rooted in soils alternately inundated and drained by tidal action.

name: Tidepools
definition: An intertidal depression in rocks or in sandy beaches that continues to hold water during low tide (also called tidal pools).

name: Mangrove Submerged Roots
definition: Intertidal zone in mangrove forests (see 1.7).

name: Sea Cliffs and Rocky Offshore Islands
definition: To be defined. Would include limestone areas

name: Coastal Caves/Karst
definition: Karsts, sea caves and other subterranean hydrological systems along the coast. (See 9.2 and 12.1).

name: Coastal Sand Dunes
definition: Dune systems (including humid dune slacks). Note that inland dune systems and sandspits along rivers or near lakes (not in deserts) are not currently covered by this classification scheme. Code this under 18. Other.

name: Coastal Brackish/Saline Lagoons/Marine Lakes
definition: Brackish to saline lagoons and lakes with at least one relatively narrow connection to the sea. Often formed from sea inlets by silting and cut off from the sea by sand or mud banks.

name: Coastal Freshwater Lakes
definition: Includes freshwater delta lagoons (see 5.5 and 5.6).

name: Arable Land
definition: Includes cereal fields, rice paddies, perennial crops, orchards and groves (but see 14.3 and 14.4). Secondary grasslands may be coded here or under 14.2, depends on the usage.

name: Pastureland
definition: Includes fertilized or re-seeded permanent grasslands, sometimes treated with selective herbicides, with very impoverished flora and fauna. Also includes secondary grasslands and wooded farmland.

name: Plantations
definition: A plantation is an intentional planting of a crop, on a larger scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming. Plantations are typically (but not exclusively) found in tropical or semitropical countries and usually require resident labourers.
examples: Examples include cotton, tobacco, sugar cane, banana, sisal, coffee, rubber, oil palm, coconut, timber trees, pineapples.

name: Rural Gardens
definition: Rural gardens are located in a rural setting, serving families whose main income comes from wage labour (rural or urban). Rural gardens differ from arable land production by the following features which are usually, but by no means in all cases, found simultaneously: (1) cropping plants for personal consumption that cannot be collected nor supplied by arable farming, (2) small plots, (3) proximity to the house, (4) fencing, (5) mixed or dense planting of a great number of annual, semi-permanent, and perennial crops, (6) a high intensity of land use, (7) land cultivation several times a year, (8) permanence of cultivation, and (9) cultivation with hand implements. These gardens also provide space and/or fodder for the raising of small animals (usually poultry, rodents and small ruminants). In extreme cases, the rural garden may be the only source of livelihood and income for the rural poor. If enough space is available, small cash crops may be produced and exchanged or sold for purchased food. Market gardens should be coded here.

name: Urban Areas
definition: Occurs throughout the world. Usually metropolitan and commercial areas dominated by asphalt, concrete and roof. Includes buildings, lawns and parks.

name: Subtropical/Tropical Heavily Degraded Former Forest
definition: Former subtropical or tropical forest that has been extensively cleared or impacted by human activities. Often there is some degree of regeneration or there are small fragments of forest remaining.

name: Water Storage Areas [over 8 ha]
definition: Generally over 8 ha. Includes reservoirs, barrages, dams and impoundments.

name: Ponds [below 8 ha]
definition: Generally below 8 ha. Includes farm ponds, stock ponds, small tanks.

name: Aquaculture Ponds
definition: For example, fish or shrimp ponds.

name: Salt Exploitation Sites
definition: Salt pans, salines, etc.

name: Excavations (open)
definition: Gravel, brick, clay pits, borrow pits and mining pools.

name: Wastewater Treatment Areas
definition: Sewage farms, settling ponds, oxidation basins, etc.

name: Irrigated Land [includes irrigation channels]
definition: Includes irrigation channels and paddy (rice) fields.

name: Seasonally Flooded Agricultural Land
definition: Including intensively managed or grazed wet meadow or pasture.

name: Canals and Drainage Channels, Ditches
definition: Linear excavations (varying enormously in size) made specifically to improve drainage of farmland, for controlling river courses, for controlling flow of water, for allowing ship movement, etc.

name: Karst and Other Subterranean Hydrological Systems [human-made]
definition: Human-made subterranean systems.

name: Marine Anthropogenic Structures
definition: Artificial reefs, docks, seawalls, rip rap, etc.

name: Mariculture Cages
definition: Cages (made out of net or mesh) located in an open environment which includes both the sea and inland brackish water areas, for the culture of organisms, both plants and animals.

name: Mari/Brackish-culture Ponds
definition: Human-made saltwater or brackish ponds for the cultivation of organisms, both plants and animals.

name: Introduced Vegetation
definition: Includes only non-cultivated species or those that have escaped from cultivation.

name: Other
definition: A habitat type not covered by any of the other categories in the system.

name: Unknown
definition: The habitat is unknown.
